content.raw:
Merged locally after resolving merge conflict and applying above patch.

Have built package that is installable for testing purposes with:

`pip install #!/philipstarkey/qtutils/downloads/qtutils-2.1.0-rc1.zip`

I'll use this release candidate to test Python 3 ports of other apps and we can do a PyPI release of qtutils 2.1.0 if all goes well so the apps can depend on it.

update.description:
This should make qtutils Python 3 compatible.

* Added __future__ imports and did Python 3 adjustments

All the small demo codes now work under python 2 and python 3. I was not able to test with labscript stuff, as that code is not python 3 compatible.
update.title: Python 3

content.raw:
I have tested that I can run a shot from runmanager through to lyse with this code, and I tested that the reraising of exceptions works.

Of course, we can't test Python 3 with labscript as you mentioned, so any uncovering of Python 3 bugs in the way labscript uses qtutils will have to be uncovered during testing the ports of those programs.

I've applied a small patch (below) to remove the `six` dependency and to avoid using the old name `Queue` for the module (convention when making Python 2/3 compatible code is to use the Python 3 name where possible - but I'm just importing the `Queue` class by itself to avoid the issue).

Also bumping the version number to 2.1.0-rc1 and will make a release zip file that can be installed for testing and porting other apps


```
#!diff

diff -r 3909992ac18d -r 021bf53b4635 qtutils/invoke_in_main.py
--- a/qtutils/invoke_in_main.py	Tue Feb 27 11:16:47 2018 +1100
+++ b/qtutils/invoke_in_main.py	Tue Feb 27 12:34:38 2018 +1100
@@ -17,17 +17,25 @@
 PY2 = sys.version_info[0] == 2
 if PY2:
     str = unicode
-    import Queue
+    from Queue import Queue
 else:
-    import queue as Queue
+    from queue import Queue
 
-import six
 import threading
 import functools
 
 from qtutils.qt.QtCore import QEvent, QObject, QCoreApplication, QTimer, QThread
 
 
+def _reraise(exc_info):
+    type, value, traceback = exc_info
+    # handle python2/3 difference in raising exception        
+    if PY2:
+        exec('raise type, value, traceback', globals(), locals())
+    else:
+        raise value.with_traceback(traceback)
+
+
 class CallEvent(QEvent):
     """An event containing a request for a function call."""
     EVENT_TYPE = QEvent.Type(QEvent.registerEventType())
@@ -129,7 +137,7 @@
     will return a list of [result,exception] where exception=[type,value,traceback]
     of the exception.  Functions are guaranteed to be called in the order
     they were requested."""
-    queue = Queue.Queue()
+    queue = Queue()
     QCoreApplication.postEvent(caller, CallEvent(queue, exceptions_in_main, fn, *args, **kwargs))
     return queue
 
@@ -153,7 +161,7 @@
     """
     result, exception = queue.get()
     if exception is not None:
-        six.reraise(*exception)
+        _reraise(exception)
     return result
 
 
diff -r 3909992ac18d -r 021bf53b4635 setup.py
--- a/setup.py	Tue Feb 27 11:16:47 2018 +1100
+++ b/setup.py	Tue Feb 27 12:34:38 2018 +1100
@@ -27,7 +27,7 @@
     BUILD_PYQT5_ICONS_RESOURCE = False
     sys.argv.remove('NO_PYQT5')
 
-VERSION = '2.0.0'
+VERSION = '2.1.0-rc1'
 
 # conditional for readthedocs environment
 on_rtd = os.environ.get('READTHEDOCS') == 'True'

```
content.html:
I have tested that I can run a shot from runmanager through to lyse with this code, and I tested that the reraising of exceptions works.

Of course, we can't test Python 3 with labscript as you mentioned, so any uncovering of Python 3 bugs in the way labscript uses qtutils will have to be uncovered during testing the ports of those programs.

I've applied a small patch (below) to remove the six dependency and to avoid using the old name Queue for the module (convention when making Python 2/3 compatible code is to use the Python 3 name where possible - but I'm just importing the Queue class by itself to avoid the issue).

Also bumping the version number to 2.1.0-rc1 and will make a release zip file that can be installed for testing and porting other apps

diff -r 3909992ac18d -r 021bf53b4635 qtutils/invoke_in_main.py
--- a/qtutils/invoke_in_main.py Tue Feb 27 11:16:47 2018 +1100
+++ b/qtutils/invoke_in_main.py Tue Feb 27 12:34:38 2018 +1100
@@ -17,17 +17,25 @@
 PY2 = sys.version_info[0] == 2
 if PY2:
     str = unicode
-    import Queue
+    from Queue import Queue
 else:
-    import queue as Queue
+    from queue import Queue

-import six
 import threading
 import functools

 from qtutils.qt.QtCore import QEvent, QObject, QCoreApplication, QTimer, QThread


+def _reraise(exc_info):
+    type, value, traceback = exc_info
+    # handle python2/3 difference in raising exception        
+    if PY2:
+        exec('raise type, value, traceback', globals(), locals())
+    else:
+        raise value.with_traceback(traceback)
+
+
 class CallEvent(QEvent):
     """An event containing a request for a function call."""
     EVENT_TYPE = QEvent.Type(QEvent.registerEventType())
@@ -129,7 +137,7 @@
     will return a list of [result,exception] where exception=[type,value,traceback]
     of the exception.  Functions are guaranteed to be called in the order
     they were requested."""
-    queue = Queue.Queue()
+    queue = Queue()
     QCoreApplication.postEvent(caller, CallEvent(queue, exceptions_in_main, fn, *args, **kwargs))
     return queue

@@ -153,7 +161,7 @@
     """
     result, exception = queue.get()
     if exception is not None:
-        six.reraise(*exception)
+        _reraise(exception)
     return result


diff -r 3909992ac18d -r 021bf53b4635 setup.py
--- a/setup.py  Tue Feb 27 11:16:47 2018 +1100
+++ b/setup.py  Tue Feb 27 12:34:38 2018 +1100
@@ -27,7 +27,7 @@
     BUILD_PYQT5_ICONS_RESOURCE = False
     sys.argv.remove('NO_PYQT5')

-VERSION = '2.0.0'
+VERSION = '2.1.0-rc1'

 # conditional for readthedocs environment
 on_rtd = os.environ.get('READTHEDOCS') == 'True'

content.raw: I'm travelling to see the eclipse so I'm away from a computer for a couple of days :). So I won't be much help for a bit, just thought I'd reply because I (mistakenly) thought the absolute path issue would be a simple fix.

content.raw: I'm running it from a unrelated directory with "python -m blacs". The import that causes problems is the one from the tabs and they get initialized after the directory is changed.
content.html: I'm running it from a unrelated directory with "python -m blacs". The import that causes problems is the one from the tabs and they get initialized after the directory is changed.

content.raw:
Ah. Then the problem is that blacs is running with the working directory set to the blacs directory. Try running it with "python -m blacs" from un unrelated directory. Though it changes directory at some point so whether that helps will depend on whether the directory changes before the import or not.

And since running in the directory is how the launchers currently work, we will have to change the launchers or change the module name. Probably changing the module name is the way to go.
content.html:
Ah. Then the problem is that blacs is running with the working directory set to the blacs directory. Try running it with "python -m blacs" from un unrelated directory. Though it changes directory at some point so whether that helps will depend on whether the directory changes before the import or not.

And since running in the directory is how the launchers currently work, we will have to change the launchers or change the module name. Probably changing the module name is the way to go.

content.raw: I'm talking about python 3 here so  ```__future__``` wont help a bit is already imported so that won't help.
content.html: I'm talking about python 3 here so __future__ wont help a bit is already imported so that won't help.

content.raw: Renaming it is not out of the question though, since having the same name as a stdlib module is bad form. But maybe later so the diffs are still useful until then.
content.html: Renaming it is not out of the question though, since having the same name as a stdlib module is bad form. But maybe later so the diffs are still useful until then.

content.raw: `from __future__ import absolute_import` should make it so that `import queue` will be the stdlib and anything wanting to import the blacs queue module will have to import `.queue` or `blacs.queue`
content.html: from __future__ import absolute_import should make it so that import queue will be the stdlib and anything wanting to import the blacs queue module will have to import .queue or blacs.queue

content.raw: For some reason qtutils imports queue.py from BLACS instead of the module queue in Python3 and that breaks loads of stuff there. So I guess that should get fixed here as we probably won't rename BLACS.queue. Any clever ideas on how we could import the right queue?
content.html: For some reason qtutils imports queue.py from BLACS instead of the module queue in Python3 and that breaks loads of stuff there. So I guess that should get fixed here as we probably won't rename BLACS.queue. Any clever ideas on how we could import the right queue?

content.raw:
I'd stick to our own PY2 for now as I don't see much benefit in the six one.

I have no idea how setup works so I'm not much help there.
content.html:
I'd stick to our own PY2 for now as I don't see much benefit in the six one.

I have no idea how setup works so I'm not much help there.

content.raw:
Yes, that's how I had it in a custom version I was playing around with a couple of years ago.

We could now consider using the six PY2 flag rather than our own, but it's perhaps not entirely worth it at this point.

We should probably also add six as an official package requirement so it gets installed by pip automatically (not sure if this should be in setup.py/requirements.txt or both)
content.html:
Yes, that's how I had it in a custom version I was playing around with a couple of years ago.

We could now consider using the six PY2 flag rather than our own, but it's perhaps not entirely worth it at this point.

We should probably also add six as an official package requirement so it gets installed by pip automatically (not sure if this should be in setup.py/requirements.txt or both)

update.description:
This should make qtutils Python 3 compatible.

* Added __future__ imports and did Python 3 adjustments

All the small demo codes now work under python 2 and python 3. I was not able to test with labscript stuff, as that code is not python 3 compatible.
update.title: Python 3

content.raw:
So I don't really have a problem with making `six` a dependency. I bring this up because our [exception raising code](#!/philipstarkey/qtutils/pull-requests/2/python-3/diff#Lqtutils/invoke_in_main.pyF98) is not as good as that in `six` and I'd rather not leave in corner case bugs in exception handling!

We could not import six, and just do what they do in [`reraise`](https://github.com/benjaminp/six/blob/master/six.py#L683), but basically everyone has six installed, so I think we may as well use it.
content.html:
So I don't really have a problem with making six a dependency. I bring this up because our exception raising code is not as good as that in six and I'd rather not leave in corner case bugs in exception handling!

We could not import six, and just do what they do in reraise, but basically everyone has six installed, so I think we may as well use it.

content.raw: Great! you missed two of the print_function imports, and I would make one suggestion about `str('widgets')'` - since `str()` is liable to be aliased to point to `unicode` in Python 2 if this module is edited in the future, it would be better not to use `str()` to refer to bytes in Python 2 - instead you could add the PY2 lines at the top as in the other files and then say `ModuleType(b'widgets' if PY2 else 'widgets')`. Much more verbose but it could lead to confusion in future to not have all files using the same aliasing for py2/py3 compatibility.
content.html: Great! you missed two of the print_function imports, and I would make one suggestion about str('widgets')' - since str() is liable to be aliased to point to unicode in Python 2 if this module is edited in the future, it would be better not to use str() to refer to bytes in Python 2 - instead you could add the PY2 lines at the top as in the other files and then say ModuleType(b'widgets' if PY2 else 'widgets'). Much more verbose but it could lead to confusion in future to not have all files using the same aliasing for py2/py3 compatibility.

content.raw:
Noticed just before you posted. It's already fixed.

Yes python2 didn't like unicode strings for ```ModuleType```.

All of the changes together took about 15-20 minutes so no sweat.

content.raw:
Looking pretty good. You now have redundant `from __future__ import print_function` lines though, as `print_function` is subsequently imported in the added `__future__` import lines.

is `ModuleType(str('widgets'))`  required because modules must be bytestrings in Python 2 but unicode strings in Python 3 (I am not sure if this is true but I think it is)? If so then this is good. 

Don't worry too much about OutputBox - I've been hacking on this and adding some functionality to it, and my new version of it is Python 3 compatible (and will have merge conflicts). So perhaps I'll make a pull request for my changes soon, and then if it gets merged before your changes you can then just ignore that file for the purposes of Python 3 compatibility (other than any bugs that become apparent). I was waiting for the qt5 merge before making a pull request about this, but it's done now so I'll just rename a few methods that I added and then make the pull request. Apologies if you spend much time on that.
content.html:
Looking pretty good. You now have redundant from __future__ import print_function lines though, as print_function is subsequently imported in the added __future__ import lines.

is ModuleType(str('widgets')) required because modules must be bytestrings in Python 2 but unicode strings in Python 3 (I am not sure if this is true but I think it is)? If so then this is good.

Don't worry too much about OutputBox - I've been hacking on this and adding some functionality to it, and my new version of it is Python 3 compatible (and will have merge conflicts). So perhaps I'll make a pull request for my changes soon, and then if it gets merged before your changes you can then just ignore that file for the purposes of Python 3 compatibility (other than any bugs that become apparent). I was waiting for the qt5 merge before making a pull request about this, but it's done now so I'll just rename a few methods that I added and then make the pull request. Apologies if you spend much time on that.
